Authors:
VINEET VISHAL, SOMNATH S MUNDA, GEETANJALI Singh, SHALINI
LAL
Title:
New distribution data on wild edible gasteroid fungus
Astraeus (Diplocystidiaceae) from India.
Abstract:
The gasteroid fungus Astraeus Phosri et al is a highly
prized wild edible mushroom, consumed in different part of India and
other Asian countries, popularly known as “earthstar” due to star-like
appearance that occur when it reaches maturity have always been subject
of great interest when found. The fruitbodies of earthstars were
ectomycorrhizal in nature and usually grows on a diverse range of
habitat like leaf litter, mossy blocks, termite mould, sand dunes, and
lateritic soil. The fruitbodies of Astraeus and its allies have
persistent endoperidium which cover hymenophore (gleba) and, spores
released passively by bellows mechanism through apical mouth but lack
peristome and columella. Expeditions to Sal forest of southern part of
Jharkhand state of India between June and July 2019 resulted into two
noteworthy earthstar species  A. asiaticus Phosri et al. and A. odoratus
Phosri et al. The earthstars are superficially similar but distinct in
morphological, anatomical and phylogenetic traits. This work aimed to
contribute to the knowledge of Astraeus diversity and distribution in
Jharkhand mycoflora based on integrative taxonomic approach using
combined morpho-anatomical, molecular and phylogenetic studies. Species
description, images of basidiomes, SEM photos of basidiospore are
provided.
